parts.question_text: Find the set of values of \(x\) that satisfy the inequality.
parts.solution_text:
We are given the inequality \(6 + 2x^2 > x(x + 4)\).
Expanding the right side gives \(6 + 2x^2 > x^2 + 4x\).
Subtracting \(x^2 + 4x\) from both sides gives \(x^2 - 4x + 6 > 0\).
Completing the square, we have \((x - 2)^2 - 4 + 6 > 0\), which simplifies to \((x - 2)^2 + 2 > 0\).
Since \((x-2)^2 \ge 0\) for all real values of \(x\), we know that \((x - 2)^2 + 2 \ge 2\) for all real values of \(x\).  Therefore, \((x - 2)^2 + 2\) is always greater than 0.
Thus, the inequality holds for all real values of \(x\).  The solution set is \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).
